'''Bull City Red''' (born '''George Washington''', [[Durham, North Carolina|Durham]], [[North Carolina]], [[United States]]) was an [[United States|American]], [[Piedmont blues]] [[guitarist]], [[singing|singer]], and predominately [[washboard]] player, most associated with [[Blind Boy Fuller]] and the [[Reverend Gary Davis]]. Little is known of Red's life outside of his recording career.

==Biography==
George Washington's primary [[nickname]], "Bull City Red", came from the 'Bull City' town of Durham, where he was born. He was sometimes alternatively called '''Oh Red'''. Although he was just good enough as a guitarist to imitate Fuller, with whom he frequently played, he was a very talented washboard player and also sang.<ref name="AMG">{{cite web |first= |last= |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p37667/biography|pure_url=yes}}|title=Biography by Bruce Eder |publisher=Allmusic.com|accessdate=December 26, 2009}}</ref> 

A partial [[albino]], Red was a street musician in Durham before becoming the sole sighted member of a band managed by talent scout [[J. B. Long]] that included at various times Fuller, [[Sonny Terry]] and Davis.<ref name="russell"/><ref name=Young>{{cite book | first = Alan | last = Young | title = Woke me up this morning: Black gospel singers and the gospel life | series = American made music series | publisher = University Press of Mississippi | year = 1997 | isbn = 0-87805-944-X | page = 11}}</ref> In 1935, then a trio featuring Red, Davis and Fuller, the band went to New York to enter the recording studio for the first time,<ref name=Young/> in a session for the [[American Record Corporation]] (ARC).<ref name=Davis>{{cite book | first = Gary | last = Davis |author2=Stefan Grossman | title = Stefan Grossman's Early Masters of American Blues Guitar: Rev. Gary Davis | publisher = Alfred Publishing | year = 1993 | isbn = 0-7390-4329-3 | page = 4}}</ref> As his collaborators were blind, Red signaled them by touch when the recording ended.<ref name=Davis/> Accompanying Fuller along with Terry, Red recorded many songs for ARC's Perfect label between 1935 and Fuller's death during surgery in 1941.<ref name="AMG"/><ref>{{cite book | first = Jean Bradley | last = Anderson | title= Durham County: a history of Durham County, North Carolina | publisher = Duke University Press | year = 1990 | isbn = 0-8223-1056-2 | page = 375}}</ref> 

Red also [[sound recording and reproduction|recorded]] [[gospel music]] based songs under the name of 'Brother George and His Sanctified Singers' along with Fuller, Terry, and Sonny Jones.<ref name="AMG"/> He recorded "I Saw the Light" with guitar backing by Davis.<ref name=Young/> On Fuller's latter day [[compilation album]], ''Get Your Yas Yas Out'', Red played the washboard on "Jitterbug Rag".<ref name="russell">{{cite book
| first= Tony
| last= Russell
| year= 1997
| title= The Blues: From Robert Johnson to Robert Cray
| edition= 
| publisher= Carlton Books Limited 
| location= Dubai
| page= 203
| isbn= 1-85868-255-X}}</ref> Between 1935 and 1939, he struck out on his own as well, recording solo with his own vocals, guitar and washboard.<ref name="AMG"/> His tracks included "Black Woman and Poison Blues" and "I Won't Be Dogged Around".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wirz.de/music/magpifrm.htm|title=Magpie Records discography|publisher=Wirz.de|accessdate=January 25, 2014}}</ref> 

In 1941, Red became involved with another band. In late 1940, he had introduced [[Brownie McGhee]] and his collaborator Jordan Webb to his manager and fellow musicians Fuller and Terry. After Fuller's death, the group came together along with another washboard player, Robert Young, to record.<ref name="AMG"/>
